ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Partner work on asynchronous days.
Live zoom seminar classes and 1 asynchronous activity every other week.
In-person language class.
None
Zoom classes and asynchronous classes with assignments for the day.
Asynchronous group exercises
No other modes of learning.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was an extremely useful intro to Polish conversation. You will learn useful vocabulary and grammar for basic situations.
I learned how to speak, write, and understand an elementary level of the Polish language
I learned basic polish spellings and grammar.
This course will teach you some basics of polish vocabulary and grammar, as well as a little bit of polish culture and history.
I learned basic Polish phrases and words.
The elementary elements of the polish language.
I learned how to pronounce polish words and form sentences.
I was able to learn grammar and vocabulary of the Polish language in order to work on my skills of reading, writing, listening, and speaking in Polish.

I learned a good amount of words and numbers, ranging from 0 to 100, and how to put simple sentences together in Polish. I learned a lot about sentence structure, and how to hold a basic conversation.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professor is phenomenal. I would highly recommend this course because she makes learning a language an enjoyable experience, while also ensuring we cover a lot of ground.
I felt like the teacher did a great job engaging the students and making learning enjoyable for me.
The course is great but i feel the zoom aspect drew away from the attentiveness of a regular year.

The course is extremely easy to keep up with yet still teaches you polish, and if you engage you won't the term having learned nothing. However it could teach the students even more if the pace over the entire semester were somewhat quicker, which may be a problem specific to having to accommodate speaking and repeating to zoom class. Professor Illakowicz provides more than enough feedback and all the opportunities a student could want to get ahead however and focus on learning polish.
Great teacher! She makes you want to come to class.
In person would be much better to fully submerged yourself in the language but it was unavailable this semester.
I think that the professors involvement was awesome. I would have liked to see our grades from quizzes and homework sooner, but her communication through the semester was great.
Meeting every day is a bit of a pain through Zoom, but that is about the only weakness. The activities are engaging and incredibly helpful in learning the language.
I believe it would have been very engaging in person. If in person, I believe I could also be able to learn more.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall the transition to zoom, involving personal discussion, response, repetition and question and answer worked well, however it slowed down the pace of class a lot.
She did a great job keeping us engaged.
It worked very well.
I thought the professor did an awesome job acclimating to these uncertain times.
I appreciated the asynchronous exercises and believe they should be incorporated more. Maybe viewing of Polish films or listening to Polish music in class would also help.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I'd absolutely recommend this course to another student. Not only is Polish an incredibly rewarding language (since it opens the door to other Slavic languages), but its taught so well at yale.
Wholeheartedly recommend. One of the best choices I made at Yale was to take Polish.
Yes. I really enjoyed the language.
Yes it is a great class taught by a great and understanding professor.
I would absolutely recommend this course to anybody interested in slavic languages, Eastern Europe, or anybody who wants a fun language with little stress.
Yes if you want an interesting and fun language.
Yes its a god language and it isnt as intensive as other languages offered.
Yes. It is a very fun language to take and the teaching was unbelievable.
Yes, I believe Polish language and culture are very interesting to learn about.
I think I would definitely recommend this course. It is a great language and very interesting to learn.
